com.innowhere.jnieasy.core.mem
Interface NativeManager

public interface NativeManager

The NativeManager interface is used to manage the native lifecycle of native capable objects and some native memory tasks.

Author:
Jose M. Arranz Santamaria
See Also:
JNIEasy.getNativeManager()

Field Detail

NOT_FREE_MEMORY

static final int NOT_FREE_MEMORY
Constant used to specify that the native memory must not be freed when a native object is being detached.

See Also:
detach(Object,int,boolean), Constant Field Values

FREE_MEMORY

static final int FREE_MEMORY
Constant used to specify that the native memory must be freed when a native object is being detached and owns its native memory.

See Also:
detach(Object,int,boolean), Constant Field Values

FORCE_FREE_MEMORY

static final int FORCE_FREE_MEMORY
Constant used to specify that the native memory must be freed unconditionally when a native object is being detached.

Native memory is freed even though the native object does not own it. Use this option with care; it is useful if the native memory was created in native code.

See Also:
detach(Object,int,boolean), Constant Field Values

setRuntimeChecking

void setRuntimeChecking(boolean check)
Sets whether the framework must check native operations on runtime.

Runtime checking improves reliability of native operations, typical operations like passing parameters on calling native methods or setting data members of a structure, are checked to verify that type and native state are valid. These checks expend some time, on deployment, with reliable code, checking may be disabled.

Parameters:
check - if true instructs the frameworks to check native operations.
See Also:
isRuntimeChecking()

isRuntimeChecking

boolean isRuntimeChecking()
Return whether the framework must check native operations on runtime.

Returns true by default.

Returns:
true if the framework performs runtime checks.
See Also:
setRuntimeChecking(boolean)

allocateBuffer

NativeBuffer allocateBuffer(long size)
Creates a new native buffer allocating the amount native memory specified with the size parameter.

The returned native buffer owns the native memory.

Parameters:
size - the native memory size to allocate
Returns:
a new allocated native buffer.

attachBuffer

NativeBuffer attachBuffer(long address)
Creates a new native buffer attached to the native memory starting in the specified address parameter.

The returned native buffer does not own the native memory, and there is no upper limit. This is useful to read data with not known size as C allocated strings.

Current implementation calls attachBuffer(long,long) with size equals to -1.

Parameters:
address - the native address to attach
Returns:
a new attached native buffer.

attachBuffer

NativeBuffer attachBuffer(long address,
                          long size)
Creates a new native buffer attached to the native memory starting in the specified address parameter and size bytes.

The returned native buffer does not own the native memory and is not possible to access data upper the address: address + size. This is useful to read data with known size.

If size is -1, memory size is unknown and there is no checking upper limits.

Parameters:
address - the native address to attach.
size - the native memory size.
Returns:
a new attached native buffer.
See Also:
attachBuffer(long)

newAddress

NativeAddress newAddress(long address)
Creates a new NativeAddress object encapsulating the native memory address submitted.

Parameters:
address - the native address to encapsulate.
Returns:
the new NativeAddress object

newAddress

NativeAddress newAddress(NativeAddress address,
                         long offset)
Creates a new NativeAddress object encapsulating the native memory address and relative offset submitted.

The returned NativeAddress object is "attached" to the address object and native address value is calculated as address.getValue() + offset

Parameters:
address - the parent NativeAddress object.
offset - the relative offset to the parent address.
Returns:
the new NativeAddress object

makeNative

boolean makeNative(java.lang.Object obj)
Makes the native capable object native, "unfetching" data members to native memory.

Native memory is allocated and object's data members are "unfetched" recursively. If a member is a persistent capable object (embedded or not) it will be made native and so on. The dependency tree of the object will be made native. Circular dependencies are detected with no problem.

Anyway, member objects are made native using different ways:

  • An embedded object member shares the memory of the parent object, therefore it will be made native invoking makeNative(Object,NativeAddress,long), using the address of parent and relative offset of the member data according the native memory attribute map.
  • A linked (not embedded) object member does not share the memory of the parent object (native memory layout of the member is a pointer), therefore it will be made native invoking makeNative(Object) and its address is copied to the pointer member of the parent.

If the object is already native, it does nothing.

The object must be an instance of a native capable class, otherwise an exception is thrown.

Parameters:
obj - object instance to make native.
Returns:
true if instance was not native before calling.
See Also:
unFetch(Object,int)

makeNative

boolean makeNative(java.lang.Object obj,
                   NativeAddress address,
                   long offset)
Makes the native capable object native, attaching to the native memory address submitted with address and offset parameters and "unfetching" data members to native memory.

The main difference with makeNative(Object) is that native memory is not allocated.

Parameters:
obj - object instance to make native.
address - native address instance to attach.
offset - relative offset.
Returns:
true if instance was not native before calling.
See Also:
attach(Object,NativeAddress,long), newAddress(NativeAddress,long)

makeNative

boolean makeNative(java.lang.Object obj,
                   long address)
Makes the native capable object native, attaching to the native memory address submitted with the address parameter and "unfetching" data members to native memory.

Current implementation is: 

 return makeNative(obj,newAddress(address),0);

Returns:
true if instance was not native before calling.
See Also:
makeNative(Object,NativeAddress,long), newAddress(long)

attach

boolean attach(java.lang.Object obj,
               NativeAddress address,
               long offset)
Attaches the native capable object to the native memory address submitted with address and offset parameters and fetching data members from native memory. The attached object will be native.

It follows a similar process as makeNative(Object,NativeAddress,long), with the following differences: native memory is not modified and is fetched to the Java data members.

Member objects are attached using different ways:

  • An embedded object member shares the memory of the parent object, therefore it will be attached invoking attach(Object,NativeAddress,long), using the address of parent and relative offset of the member data according the native memory attribute map.
  • A linked (not embedded) object member does not share the memory of the parent object (native memory layout of the member is a pointer), therefore it will be attached invoking attach(Object,long) using as address the value of the pointer member from native memory.

The dependency tree of the object will be made native. Circular dependencies are detected with no problem.

It does nothing if the object is already attached to the submitted address and offset, otherwise an exception is thrown.

Parameters:
obj - object instance to attach.
address - native address instance to attach.
offset - relative offset.
Returns:
true if instance was not native before calling.
See Also:
newAddress(NativeAddress,long), fetch(Object,int)

attach

boolean attach(java.lang.Object obj,
               long address)
Attaches the native capable object native to the native memory address submitted with address parameter and fetching data members from native memory.

Current implementation is: 

 return attach(obj,newAddress(address),0);

Parameters:
obj - object instance to attach.
address - native address instance to attach.
Returns:
true if instance was not native before calling.
See Also:
attach(Object,NativeAddress,long), newAddress(long)

free

boolean free(java.lang.Object obj)
Frees the native object, the native memory is freed if object owns it.

Member embedded objects are freed too, but linked member objects keep as native.

A freed object is not native.

Current implementation is: 

 return detach(obj,FREE_MEMORY,false);

Parameters:
obj - object instance to free.
Returns:
true is the object was native before calling.
See Also:
detach(Object,int,boolean)

detach

boolean detach(java.lang.Object obj)
Detaches the native object but not free the native memory.

Member embedded objects are detached too, but linked member objects keep as native.

A detached object is not native.

Current implementation is: 

 return detach(obj,NOT_FREE_MEMORY,false);

Parameters:
obj - object instance to detach.
Returns:
true is the object was native before calling.
See Also:
detach(Object,int,boolean)

detach

boolean detach(java.lang.Object obj,
               int freeMemMode,
               boolean deep)
Detaches the native object.

Native memory is freed following the rules of freeMemMode parameter with values: NOT_FREE_MEMORY,FREE_MEMORY, FORCE_FREE_MEMORY.

Member embedded objects are detached too. If deep parameter is true, linked member objects are detached too recursively, using the same freeMemMode and deep parameters. The dependency tree of the object will be detached. Circular dependencies are detected with no problem.

If the object is not native does nothing.

A detached object is not native.

Parameters:
obj - object instance to free.
freeMemMode - free memory condition.
deep - true if linked objects must be detached too recursively.
Returns:
true is the object was native before calling.

detachCopy

java.lang.Object detachCopy(java.lang.Object obj)
Makes a detached clone of a native object.

The dependency tree (member native objects and relationships) of the native object is fully cloned, no changes are performed in the original and dependent objects and native memory is not fetched.

Circular dependencies are detected with no problem.

Parameters:
obj - native object to clone.
Returns:
the cloned object
See Also:
detach(Object), attachCopy(Object,Object)

attachCopy

void attachCopy(java.lang.Object nativeObj,
                java.lang.Object detachedObj)
Copy the content of a non native object to a native object.

Both objects must have same type, otherwise an exception is thrown.

The non native object is left as is, but member native capable objects are made native and member of the native object to copy.

Parameters:
nativeObj - the native object to copy to.
detachedObj - the non native object to copy from.
See Also:
detachCopy(Object)

fetch

void fetch(java.lang.Object obj)
Fetches the native memory data to the native members of the native object synchronizing native memory and "Java memory".

Current implementation calls fetch(Object,int) with the current default fetch mode.

Parameters:
obj - the native object to fetch.
See Also:
getDefaultFetchMode()

fetch

void fetch(java.lang.Object obj,
           int mode)
Fetches the native memory data to the native members of the native object synchronizing native memory and "Java memory".

The mode parameter, with values Fetch.FAST, Fetch.EMBEDDED, and Fetch.DEEP, instructs how "deep" is the fetch.

Parameters:
obj - the native object to fetch.
mode - the fetch mode.
See Also:
unFetch(Object,int)

unFetch

void unFetch(java.lang.Object obj)
"Unfetches" the native members of the native object to the native memory data, synchronizing native memory and "Java memory".

Current implementation calls unFetch(Object,int) with the current default "unfetch" mode.

Parameters:
obj - the native object to fetch.
See Also:
getDefaultUnFetchMode()

unFetch

void unFetch(java.lang.Object obj,
             int mode)
"Unfetches" the native members of the native object to the native memory data, synchronizing native memory and "Java memory".

The mode parameter, with values UnFetch.FAST, UnFetch.EMBEDDED, and UnFetch.DEEP, instructs how "deep" is the "unfetch".

Parameters:
obj - the native object to "unfetch".
mode - the "unfetch" mode.
See Also:
fetch(Object,int)

findObject

java.lang.Object findObject(long address)
Finds the native object with the submitted address in the native object registry. If found is returned else returns null.

The registry only contains objects that own their native memory. When a native capable object is made native and owns their native memory, is automatically registered.

When the framework needs a native object corresponding to a native address, (for instance a returned address of the invocation of a native method) always looks in the registry first, if does not exist then creates a new native object and attach to the address.

The insertion in the registry does not prevent that a native object can be garbage collected. When a native object is garbage collected is removed from the registry automatically.

Parameters:
address - the native address to look for.
See Also:
getObject(Class,long)

getObject

java.lang.Object getObject(java.lang.Class cls,
                           long address)
Gets the object linked to the submitted address or constructs and attaches a new object if there is no native object in the registry with this address.

The cls parameter must be a native capable Class (user defined or framework defined) or a "can be native" class (as primitive wrappers, Java arrays, String etc).

If cls is a "can be native" class, the method returns the wrapped object of the native object found in the registry or the new wrapper object attached to the address, using the method NativeSingleFieldContainer.getValue(). This ensures that the returned "can be native" object value is synchronized with the native memory.

The returned object is ensured its type of specified Class.

If a new object is created, it is created with new using the default constructor without parameters, reflection is only used with multidimensional Java arrays (for instance int[][].class).

Parameters:
cls - the expected class type of returned object.
address - the native address to look for or attach.
Returns:
the object found or created and attached.
See Also:
findObject(long)

currentTransaction

NativeTransaction currentTransaction()
Returns the NativeTransaction manager of the caller thread.

Returns:
the transaction object.

addInstanceLifecycleListener

void addInstanceLifecycleListener(InstanceLifecycleListener listener,
                                  java.lang.Class[] classes)
Adds the listener instance to the list of lifecycle event listeners.

The classes parameter identifies all classes of interest to the listener.

The listener will be called for each event for which it implements the corresponding listener interface.

If the classes parameter is null, events of the listener type for all native classes will be sent to this listener.

Parameters:
listener - the lifecycle listener
classes - the classes of interest to the listener
See Also:
removeInstanceLifecycleListener(InstanceLifecycleListener)

removeInstanceLifecycleListener

void removeInstanceLifecycleListener(InstanceLifecycleListener listener)
Removes the listener instance from the list of lifecycle event listeners.

Parameters:
listener - the listener instance to be removed
See Also:
addInstanceLifecycleListener(InstanceLifecycleListener,Class[])
